feed.title: Interview: Rise Against Dare to Care
feed.subtitle: Since 1999 Rise Against has been mixing catchy music with a political message. Says frontman Tim McIlrath, "it's the sugar-coated bitter pill."

link.Abstract: Since 1999 Rise Against has been mixing catchy music with a political message. Says frontman Tim McIlrath, "it's the sugar-coated bitter pill."
link.title: Rise Against

link.Abstract: Get the latest music news, interviews and album reviews
link.title: Get the latest music news, interviews and album reviews

content.div:
For your consideration: A strictly vegetarian, predominantly straight edge, tree-huggin' hardcore band that -- far from letting the good times roll -- insists, both on and offstage, on advancing the cause of a dizzying array of social justice and human rights issues. And stuff.

Sounds like a party.

Well, in actual fact, it is. Since Rise Against's 1999 formation in Chicago, the punk-influenced melodic hardcore foursome have been subject to the kind of mass embrace that might have broken the back of a weaker band. But it would seem that the courage of their convictions is both the source of their continued strength and the key to their mainstream crossover success.

Fronted by outspoken musician activist Tim McIlrath -- who is joined by guitarist Zach Blair, bassist Joe Principe and drummer Brandon Barnes -- Rise Against have, over the course of six very well-received albums in only 10 years, including the recently released Endgame, helped make caring cool. And very listenable.

"It's such a balancing act trying to combine art and politics and create a message, but still create something that's compelling for the listener," McIlrath says. "You could have the most important message in the world, but if you don't have a catchy chorus, no one's gonna hear it. So it's the sugar-coated bitter pill."

Catchy choruses don't appear to be an issue. Rise Against can be credited with a remarkable level of consistency in terms of the quality of the band's recorded output, never failing to land, at minimum, a couple of epic tracks -- hit songs like "Prayer of the Refugee," "Saviour" and "Re-Education (Through Labor)" -- with each album release. And contrary to the typically bell-curved career path of most socially conscious mainstream punk bands, Rise Against continues to enjoy an upward trajectory.

The most recent full-length, Endgame, for example, debuted on the U.S. Billboard 200 at No. 2, their highest posting yet. It's a fairly safe bet that Endgame will follow in the footsteps of the band's three preceding albums -- Siren Song of the Counter Culture (2004), The Sufferer & the Witness (2006) and Appeal to Reason (2008) -- to certified gold status in the U.S., and platinum in Canada.

These are remarkable achievements for any band, never mind a deeply politically engaged hardcore band, something that's not lost on McIlrath.

"The Billboard charts were never really anything I put a lot of stock in," he states, "and we didn't start Rise Against with the goal of being part of that world.

"So to see our name up there right next to, like, Adele and Lady Gaga or something like that is really strange. Deep down in my heart I'm delusional and I still think we're a basement garage band."

A basement garage band that has, in virtually every respect, grown into adulthood. McIlrath, now a father of two, notes that the addition of kids has brought an elevated sense of purpose to the band's mission, and a greater awareness of the needs of Rise Against's predominantly youthful fan base.

"(Fatherhood) makes me reflect on who we are as a band, where we fit in people's lives and what kind of audience we're speaking to," McIlrath says.

"I'm a realist in the way that I know the whole world doesn't listen to Rise Against, and Rise Against isn't welcome in some circles.

"So I try to figure out what world we do fit into, and what kind of person is looking to us, and what responsibility I have as someone who inhabits their CD player or iPod."

The exercise of that responsibility can be found in the towering first two singles off Endgame: the urgent, self-explanatory "Help Is on the Way" (a pounding paean to the victims of Hurricane Katrina) and the heart -- and sound system -- rending "Make It Stop (September's Children)," pertaining to the much-publicized spate of suicides by gay American teens in September 2010.

"Make It Stop (September's Children)" took on added resonance recently following the headline-making death of Jamey Rodemeyer in Buffalo, N.Y., Sept. 18. The 14-year-old -- who is alleged to have taken his own life as a result of anti-gay bullying -- isn't far from McIlrath's mind.

"This is such a sad case," McIlrath says.

"We were in Buffalo just a few days ago and we dedicated 'Make It Stop' to Jamey Rodemeyer. Then we actually met some of his friends at a record signing, which was really sad. Here was a kid who filmed a video, talked about how he was bullied, how it could get better, how he survived it and then five months later decides he can't survive it anymore. Obviously it wasn't enough, and it serves as a reminder that the fight continues."

Canadian Tour Dates Include:

Oct. 7, Saskatoon

Oct. 8, Edmonton

Oct. 9, Calgary

Oct. 11, Victoria

Oct. 12, Vancouver
